column9: Description
Prof.Albert explains to Granny the meaning of the term 'Machine Learning'
Prof.Albert explains to Granny the concept of slope of a line
Prof.Albert explains to Granny the concept of 'Gradient Descent' and how it helps in minimizing the cost function.
Prof.Albert explains to Granny the concept of a 'Cost Function' and it is usage in the Machine Learning world
Prof.Albert explains to our Granny the concept of 'Differentiation' and how it is used to calculate the gradients for the cost function
Prof.Albert explains the difference between a model and an algorithm to our Granny
Prof.Albert explains to Granny how linear regression equation can be used to predict house prices
A Statquest for R Squared that explains the best fit line found by a Linear Regression Algorithm.

While root means square error and accuracy rate are the two most popular metrics used in evaluating model performance in cross validation, there are limitations of using these when the performance is more important for the researcher in one section of the data than the other

We review / introduce the concepts of basic probability, odds, and the odds ratio and then apply them to a quick logistic regression example. Understanding these concepts is crucial to knowing what logistic regression does and the ability to interpret computer output after running logistic regression.

Odds Ratios and Log(Odds Ratios) are like R-Squared - they describe a relationship between two things. And just like R-Squared, you need to determine if this relationship is statistically significant.
A sigmoid function can convert any real value sample to a probability range of 0 to 1 this property of sigmoid help's to utilize it logistic regression problems.
Cross Entropy is the cost function used in Logistic Regression model.
This video explains how the coefficients are obtained in a Logistic Regression model.
Decision Tree classifiers are intuitive, interpretable, and algorithms. I?ll introduce concepts including Decision Tree Learning, Gini Impurity, and Information Gain.

#BiasVarianceTradeOff #Overfitting #UnderFitting #MachineLearning #DataAnalytics #DataScience Bias Variance Trade off is an important concept when it comes to choosing a machine learning algorithm for you problem. Bias is the expectation in error and variance is the variability in the model.
This video explains the concept of Gini Coefficient using simple illustrations for Decision Trees.
This video explains the importance of entropy and information gain while building a Decision Tree
This video explains the hyperparameters that can be tuned for building a decision tree
This video explains the concept of bagging used to build a Random Forest
Want to learn why Random Forests are one of the most popular and most powerful supervised Machine Learning algorithm in Machine Learning?
This video explains how Gridsearch can be performed on Random Forest
Introduction to the central limit theorem and the sampling distribution of the mean
In this video I describe how the k Nearest Neighbors algorithm works, and provide a simple example using 2-dimensional data and k = 3.

In this tutorial, we continue our introduction to similarity and dissimilarity by discussing euclidean distance and cosine similarity. We will show you how to calculate the euclidean distance and construct a distance matrix
Machine Learning Technical Interview: Manhattan and Euclidean Distance, l1 l2 norm
Euclidean/Minkowski Metric, Spacelike, Timelike, Lightlike
What is Mahalanobis Distance? Where it is used in linear discriminant analysis? Issues with Euclidian distance
In this video, Prof.Albert explains the importance of PCA to Granny with the help of a 'Pizza' example.
This video explains the problems faced by algorithms when faced with a lot of features
Prof.Albert explains the importance of choosing attributes that explain the maximum variance in a dataset
Prof.Albert visually explains to Granny how PCA comes up with the new attributes.
Prof.Albert explains to Granny the motivation for performing PCA - "Linear Systems"
This video explains the K-means clustering technique in detail using Euclidean distance
This video explains the K-median clustering technique and explains how it is better than K-mean clustering.
Hierarchical clustering is often used with heatmaps and with machine learning type stuff. It's no big deal, though, and based on just a few simple concepts

This algorithm works by assigning membership to each data point corresponding to each cluster centre based on the distance between the cluster centre and the data point. More the data is near to the cluster centre more is its membership towards the particular cluster centre.
This video talks about Density-based clustering
ROC (Receiver Operator Characteristic) graphs and AUC (the area under the curve), are useful for consolidating the information from a ton of confusion matrices into a single, easy to interpret graph.
This video talks about calculating F1-score using Precision and Recall
One of the fundamental concepts in machine learning is Cross Validation. It's how we decide which machine learning method would be best for our dataset.
This video explains how K-fold Cross Validation can be used to optimize a model.
In this episode we will talk about the grid search and its benefits in choosing the best parameters of the model.
This video explains the basic concept of a Neural Network
This video explains how Neural Networks learn using Gradient Descent
This video explains how Backpropagation works in a Neural Network
This video explains the calculus behind Backpropagation in a Neural Network
Histograms are one of the most basic statistical tools that we have. They are also one of the most powerful and most frequently used.
Here we demystify what a statistical distribution is
The normal, or Gaussian, distribution is the most common distribution in all of statistics. Here I explain the basics of how these distributions are created and how they should be interpreted.
The binomial distribution and the related statistical test look really complicated, but a actually quite simple.
A friendly introduction to Bayes Theorem and Hidden Markov Models, with simple examples. No background knowledge needed, except basic probability.

A visual description of Bayes' Theorem and the Naive Bayes algorithm, and an application to spam detection. No previous knowledge is needed, aside from knowing how to multiply and divide, a visual mind and a desire to learn.
This video explains the concept of classification of text from a set of documents using a Naive Bayes Classifier approach.
This video gives a detailed overview of the SVM algorithm
This video explains the famous Kernel trick used by SVM algorithm

The Lagrange multiplier technique is how we take advantage of the fact that the solution to a constrained optimization problem occurs when the contour lines of the function being maximized are tangent to the constraint curve.
Different types of recommendation systems along with the most commonly used measures
Explains the collaborative filtering technique used by Recommendation Engines
A friendly introduction to recommender systems with matrix factorization and how it's used to recommend movies in Netflix.
